questions.question: Reconnaissance: Who could be the target of a Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack?
questions.optionA: A random user of a website
questions.optionB: A frequent user of a website

questions.question: Reconnaissance: What might be vulnerable to a Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack?
Weaponization: Which of these are not how a malicious script may try to evade detection?
questions.optionC: Filtering by web application or browser

questions.question: Weaponization: What is the most common programming language used for XSS attacks?
Delivery: Which XSS attack involves a malicious script being installed on a website's database?
Delivery: Which XSS attack involves the user clicking a malicious link?
Delivery: Which XSS attack is also known as client-side XSS?
Exploitation: What can an XSS attack do?
questions.optionB: Send requests to the web server
questions.optionC: Access the victim's cookies or local storage

questions.question: Exploitation: Who/What executes the malicious script?
Installation: Which of the following could an XSS script install?
Installation: What might an XSS attack install?
questions.optionA: A script that runs everytime the victim visits the web application
questions.optionB: A web shell that allows the attacker to remotely execute commands
questions.optionD: An XSS attack can't install anything

questions.question: Command and Control (C2): How does the attacker communicate with the malicious code?
Command and Control(C2): What can the attacker do after an attack is initiated?
Actions on Objectives: What might be the desired outcome of a successful attack?
questions.optionB: Remote control of the victim's web browser

questions.question: Actions on Objectives: Which is unlikely to be the goal of an XSS attack?
questions.optionB: Remote control of the victim's web browser
